Comments_List: How to work with everyday found objects as well as wood. How to make molds, casts, how to join materials together, how to construct an object in 3-D space. How to speak and think about sculpture!

knowledge of building basic structures, common methods used in sculpture-making, how to give critique on 3-D objects, and how to utilize library and online research in the process of developing a project
How to create and think about sculptures.
This was my first time taking a sculpture class, and I learned a lot the process of choosing mediums and engaging with space/time.
Basic practices and vocabularies of sculpture making, artistic challenges, and intriguing lectures

Strengths: Flexible workspace and open-ended prompts allow for comfort among a range of abilities.

Weaknesses: Messy and unclear calendar led to confusion about the amount of time allotted for each project. Also, there is a hierarchy between who can afford to buy certain materials as opposed to those who must find and re-use scraps.

Not really many weaknesses other than a general lack of materials, but this is not that important in an art class which is more about the theory of sculpting. Strengths are the open-ended structure and great support from teachers.

The projects are very open ended, which was very intimidating for me at first. However, over the course I really learned to take advantage of the amount of agency we get and go with it. It would have been a little more helpful to get a little more guidance towards the beginning of the course.

Erika was really nice and I felt like she gave us a lot of freedom to create the art we wanted to create. However, as an intro course, I wish there would have been a little more structure.  The professor was willing to show us how to use tools and materials, but sometimes I didn't know what to ask about because I don't have a ton of experience with sculpture materials. Also our $150 mandatory materials fee was spent on a lot of materials that the class didn't end up using. The materials bought were bought without student input, which meant that if we wanted to use anything else for our project we had to buy that on top of the fee we'd already paid. This was really frustrating as someone who doesn't have excess money to spend on art supplies. I'd prefer to have bought supplies individually without paying the fee or have input as to how the class money was spent.
Yes - it will make you see the world and your art in a new light, but be prepared to put in time, thought, and work.
I would recommend this class to someone who has already some type of experience in art, or it might be overwhelming to become suddenly immersed in a class without a lot of guidance.
Yes. It was a good and fun course.
